div1.head: Notes on the life of Henry Rose Carter, [19--]
div1.p:
Henry Rose Carter, sanitarian, b. Clifton
Plantation, Caroline Co., Va. Aug. 25, 18521; son
of Henry Rose Carter and his wife Emma
Caroline Coleman; C. E., U of Va. 1873; post
grad. work in mathematics and applied chemistry,
same, 1874, 1875; M. D., U of Md. Sch. of Medicine,
1879; married Laura Hook of St. Louis, Moo.,
Sept. 29. 1880.

Entered Marine Hospital Service (now U.S. Pub-
lic Health Service) as asst. surgeon, May 5. 1879;
passed asst. surgeon July 1, 1882; surgeon Feb. 1.
1892; sr. surgeon Oct 15. 1912; asst. surgeon. gen.
by special act of Congress since Mch 14 1915.
Has devoted attention mainly to sanitation in
connection with yellow fever and malaria, be-
ginning at the Ship Island Quarantine Sta-
tion on Gulf of Mexico 1888; had charge in con-
trol of several yellow fever epidemics in
Southern States; discoverer, in 1900-1, of ex-
trunsic incubation of yellow fever, this announce
ment leading to later discovery of Doctor Walter
Reed, that mosquitoes are carriers of yellow
fever; inaugurated quarantine system in
Cuba 1899, 1900; director of hospitals Panama
Canal Zone, 1904-9; has made a special stu-
dy of impounded waters as affecting malaria
Member Am Soc Tropical Medicine and Hygeine,
2
Royal Soc. Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (London),
Canal Zone Med. Soc; asso. mem. Baltimore
Med. and Clin. Soc., etc.

Has written about 30 articles in Pub. Health
Reports and medical journals pertaining to
yellow fever, impounded water, malaria, arti-
cles on yellow fever in The Practice of Medicine
in the Tropics, Nelson Loose-Leaf Medicine, and
Abt's System of Pediatrics.

Member Rockefeller Yellow Fever Commission
sent to Central and So. America, 1916; in charge
malarial work for U.S.P.H.S., 1917 and 1918 with
special reference to anti-malarial measures
for cantonments; yellow-fever work, Peru, S.A.,
and sanitary advisor Peruvian Govt. 1920-21.
Member Yellow Fever Council, International
Health Board, Rockefeller Foundation; hon.
chairman Natl. Malaria Com., also vice
permanent secretary

Name was presented for Nobel prize 1904
by Maj. Sir Ronald Ross.

Club; Authors (London) Cosmos Club
(Washington, D.C.)
Died ~ Sept 14th 1925
